Title: Object: Papyrus Ramesseum 8
Description: P. Ramesseum 8, Frame 14. Papyrus written on the recto in hieratic script, while the verso is blank. The recto contains a magical text against headaches known as The Banquet of Hedjhotep. The text is written in horizontal with some vertical lines. This frame contains pages 14-15. The papyrus was a half-height roll. In this page the magician threatens to hinder the sailing of the sun-god Re and to 'smash two oars in the divine bark' (lines 6-7, Gardiner, The Ramesseum Papyri, 1955, 12) The papyrus is part of the collection of papyri found with a bundle of pens in a chest from a plundered late 13th dynasty tomb under the Ramesseum, apparently belonging to someone like a lector priest. Two of the papyri from the chest are in the Egyptian Museum Berlin (P. Ramesseum A and D); the objects are in the Fitzwilliam Museum Cambridge and the Manchester Museum. The papyri are very fragile, apparently due to dampness in the tomb-shaft. This papyrus was mounted on sheets of gelatin by Hugo Ibscher.
Curator's comments: P. Ramesseum 8 page 14. A. H. Gardiner, The Ramesseum Papyri (Oxford: Oxford University Press 1955), 11-12, pl. 39. P. Meyrat, Le Papyrus Ramesseum VIII (Geneva: University of Geneva 2002), 20, pl. 14/15 [dissertation]. On the conservation of the papyri: B. Leach, 'A conservation history of the Ramesseum Papyri', JEA 92 (2006), 225-40. On the tomb: R. B. Parkinson, Reading Ancient Egyptian Poetry: Among Other Histories (Chichester and Malden: Wiley-Blackwell 2009), 138-72.
Bibliographic references: Meyrat 2019 / Les papyrus magiques du Ramesseum. Recherches sur une bibliothèque privée de la fin du Moyen Empire (41–74, 307–323)
